conclusion: Understanding what a velocity-time graph tells us.
In a velocity-time graph, the x-axis is time and the y-axis is velocity. The slope gives acceleration.
If the slope is positive, acceleration is positive; if negative, acceleration is negative.
From 0 to 1 second, velocity increases from 10 m/s to 20 m/s.
The slope from 0 to 1 second is positive, meaning positive acceleration.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the graph is curved, and velocity seems to decrease slightly.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the slope is negative, meaning negative acceleration.
Linear motion typically means straight-line motion, but in a graph, it means a straight line.
A straight line in a v-t graph indicates constant acceleration, which isn't the case here.
Linear motion refers to moving in a straight line, and decreasing acceleration means acceleration decreases over time.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the curve is concave down, meaning the slope (acceleration) is decreasing.
The acceleration is decreasing during 1 to 2 seconds.
Since the graph is curved, the motion isn't linear in the sense of constant acceleration.
In physics, linear motion means straight-line motion, which can have varying acceleration.
The particle is moving in a straight line, and the acceleration is gradually decreasing from 1 to 2 seconds.
At t=1 second, velocity is around 20 m/s; at t=2 seconds, it's around 15 m/s.
The slope is negative throughout from 1 to 2 seconds, decreasing in magnitude.
Acceleration is the first derivative of velocity; jerk is the second derivative.
From t=1 to t=2 seconds, velocity is decreasing, meaning negative acceleration.
The slope of the graph is getting more negative, meaning acceleration is decreasing (more negative).
The statement about linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds is correct.
Based on analysis, yes, it's correct to say the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration.
